source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: In Zr-Nb irradiated at about $6 6 0 ~ \mathrm { \bf K }$ to a fluence of $\mathbf { 5 . 8 } \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n \cdot m ^ { - 2 } H o l t }$ EMP et al [14] observed the following: a very low density of coarse loops with $\langle a \rangle$ - type Burgers vectors, residual $\langle a \rangle$ and $\langle c \rangle$ component network dislocations from the initial cold work, and fine precipitates $( \sim 0 . 3 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ not present prior to irradiation.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: a very low density of coarse loops with $\langle a \rangle$ - type Burgers vectors

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: residual $\langle a \rangle$ and $\langle c \rangle$ component network dislocations from the initial cold work

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: fine precipitates $( \sim 0 . 3 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ not present prior to irradiation

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: the transient negative strains at low fluence (Fig. 4a) are believed to be related to flux-enhanced precipitation

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: As niobium is precipitated, densification occurs, causing dimensional changes

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: Solute niobium atoms are also expected [18, 19] to bind preferentially to zirconium interstitial atoms, thus affecting the availability of interstitials (and vacancies through recombination) to partake in the relevant growth mechanisms

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: As the solute concentration becomes very low, the more normal dislocation-related growth mechanism dominates and a positive growth rate similar to Zircaloy is established

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: At higher temperatures, the precipitation process is expected to occur [20, 21] but the thermally activated dislocation growth mechanism apparently begins to dominate at a lower fluence, Fig. 4b

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: In recrystallized Zircaloy it was indicated earlier in the discussion that the high growth strains are believed to depend on formation of a dislocation network structure consisting of both $\langle a \rangle$ -type loops and $\langle c \rangle$ component dislocations

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: With the formation during irradiation of $\langle c \rangle$ component dislocations in recrystallized material the structures of recrystallized and coldworked Zircaloy become similar, resulting in similar growth behavior

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: In irradiated EXCEL, Holt et al [14] report a high density of fine loops with $\langle a \rangle$ -type Burgers vectors and network dislocations with $\langle c \rangle$ component Burgers vectors similar to those seen in Zircaloy

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: No niobium precipitates were observed in the alpha grains of EXCEL, probably because the niobium is concentrated in the beta phase located in the grain boundaries

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: At the higher temperatures the growth rates of Zircaloy and EXCEL are similar

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: at the lower temperatures the growth of EXCEL is, in fact, not greater than that for Zircaloy-4 plate irradiated in these experiments

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: The trend in growth with fluence for the three Zircaloy-2 materials (slab, J plate, Plate B) is generally similar

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: the Zircaloy-4 plate A shows a sharp increase to higher growth at significantly lower fluences than for the Zircaloy-2 data

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: the Zircaloy-4 strains at the higher fluences are greater than those for EXCEL

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: Observation of ⟨c⟩ component dislocations, in addition to ⟨a⟩ - type loops and dislocations, in all of the alloys (excluding zirconium)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: the strain contribution from loops is insignificant compared with the measured strains in all the materials except pure zirconium

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: For recrystallized Zircaloy, the structure controlling growth evolves during irradiation

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: the residual cold-worked dislocation structure dominates the growth at low fluences

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: For zirconium, which has few precipitates, a network dislocation structure is not stable, resulting in small observed growth

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: The present results clearly indicate that a changing solute concentration in Zr-2.5Nb affects the growth rate

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: Growth and growth rate in Zircaloy are continuously increasing with fluence up to 16.9×10²⁵ n·m⁻² and show no tendency to saturation in either recrystallized or cold-worked material

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: the growth strain magnitudes are similar for recrystallized and cold-worked Zircaloy, achieving positive strains of 1.5% and negative strains 2 to 2.5% at the highest fluences and temperatures

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: positive strains of 1.5%

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: negative strains 2 to 2.5%

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: Post-irradiation annealing experiments at 788 and 873 K indicate only insignificant recovery of the growth strain (<0.05%) in both materials

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: Post-irradiation annealing experiments at 788 and 873 K indicate only insignificant recovery of the growth strain (<0.05%) in both materials

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: The growth rate in Zircaloy increases sharply with temperature above about 670 K

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: Growth strain is a strong function of alloy content and can vary by as much as an order of magnitude, depending on fluence and temperature

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: Minor microstructural or chemical differences in nominally similar Zircaloy materials can apparently cause significant differences in growth behavior

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: The transition to a well-defined dependence on texture in Zr-2.5Nb is a function of fluence and temperature

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: In recrystallized Zircaloy, ⟨c⟩ component dislocations are generated on irradiation

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8
evidence_span: in cold-worked materials residual ⟨a⟩ and ⟨c⟩ component dislocation structures survive irradiation to high fluences

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk9
evidence_span: in Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry: Third Conference. ASTM STP 633, American Society for Testing and Materials. 1977. pp. 344364.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk9
evidence_span: at lower irradiation temperatures and fluences most growth strain in recrystallized Zircaloy is recoverable

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk9
evidence_span: the irradiation growth of Zircaloy depends on temperature and is independent in the temperature range 640 to 670 K

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk9
evidence_span: the temperature dependence of the growth strain is small compared with the larger temperature dependence above 670 K

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk9
evidence_span: the in-reactor creep rate for Zircaloy experiences a marked increase at irradiation temperatures in the same temperature range where we have observed the growth rate increase

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk9
evidence_span: the increase in the creep rate is thought to be associated in some way with the increases in dislocation mobility and vacancy diffusion rates
